ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Prerequisites/Preconditions] To use the elements in the AirSyncBase namespace, include the namespace in the command request.
[In Prerequisites/Preconditions] The namespace is included by adding the following to the command request: <CommandName xmlns:airsyncbase="ClassName:">
[In Prerequisites/Preconditions] For a complete example, see [MS-ASCMD] section 4.10.1.1.
[In Vendor-Extensible Fields] The Type element can be extended to include custom message types.
[In Vendor-Extensible Fields] For more details, see section 2.2.2.22.4.

[In Transport] The elements specified in the following sections are sent and received by using the ItemOperations, MeetingResponse, Search, SmartForward, and Sync commands, as specified in [MS-ASCMD].
[In Message Syntax] The XML schema for the AirSyncBase namespace is described in section 6.
[In Namespaces] This specification [MS-ASAIRS] defines and references various XML namespaces using the mechanisms specified in [XMLNS].

[In Namespaces] Although this specification [MS-ASAIRS] associates a specific XML namespace prefix for each XML namespace that is used, the choice of any particular XML namespace prefix is implementation-specific and not significant for interoperability.
[In Namespaces] None prefix is used for namespace URI "AirSyncBase".
[In Namespaces] The prefix "airsync" is used for namespace URI "AirSync", which refers to "[MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.21".
[In Namespaces] The prefix "email2" is used for namespace URI "Email2", which refers to "[MS-ASEMAIL] section 2.2".
[In Namespaces] The prefix "itemoperations" is used for namespace URI "ItemOperations", which refers to "[MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.1.10".
[In Namespaces] The prefix "meetingresponse" is used for namespace URI "MeetingResponse", which refers to "[MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.1.11".
[In Namespaces] The prefix "search" is used for namespace URI "Search", which refers to "[MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.1.16".
[In Namespaces] The prefix "composemail" is used for namespace URI "ComposeMail", which refers to "[MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.1.19".
[In Namespaces] The prefix "xs" is used for namespace URI "http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema", which refers to "[XMLSCHEMA1]".
[In Elements] The following table summarizes the set of common XML schema element definitions defined by this specification [MS-ASAIRS].
[In Elements] XML schema element definitions that are specific to a particular operation are described with the operation.
[In Elements] The Accuracy (section 2.2.2.1) element specifies the accuracy of the values of the Latitude and Longitude elements
[In Elements] The Add (section 2.2.2.2) element specifies adds an attachment to a calendar item or to a draft email item.
[In Elements] The AllOrNone (section 2.2.2.3) element specifies whether to search, synchronize, or retrieve all or none of the content based on the TruncationSize element.
[In Elements] The Altitude (section 2.2.2.4) element specifies the altitude of an event's location.
[In Elements] The AltitudeAccuracy (section 2.2.2.5) element specifies the accuracy of the value of the Altitude element altitude of an event's location.
[In Elements] The Annotation (section 2.2.2.6) element specifies a note about the location of an event.
[In Elements] The Attachment (section 2.2.2.7) element specifies the attachment information for a single attachment item.
[In Elements] The Attachments (section 2.2.2.8) element contains a collection of elements that contains one or more attachment items.
[In Elements] The Body (section 2.2.2.9) element specifies a collection of elements that specifies a free-form, variable-length data field associated with a stored item on the server.
[In Elements] The BodyPart (section 2.2.2.10) element specifies a collection of elements that contains the message part of the body of an e-mail.

[In Elements] The BodyPartPreference (section 2.2.2.11) element specifies a collection of elements that sets the preference information related to the type and size of information that is returned from searching, synchronizing, or fetching a BodyPart.

[In Elements] The BodyPreference (section 2.2.2.12) specifies a collection of elements that sets the preference information related to the type and size of information that is returned from searching, synchronizing, or fetching.
[In Elements] The City (section 2.2.2.13) specifies the city in which an event occurs.
[In Elements] The ClientId (section 2.2.2.14) specifies a client-generated temporary identifier that links to the file that is being added as an attachment.
[In Elements] The Content (section 2.2.2.15) contains the content of the attachment that is being added.
[In Elements] The ContentId (section 2.2.2.16) element contains an attachment's unique object that is used to reference the attachment within the item to which the attachment belongs.
[In Elements] The ContentLocation (section 2.2.2.17) element contains an attachment's relative URI, which is used to associate the attachment in other items.

[In Elements] The ContentType (section 2.2.2.18) element specifies the type of data that is contained either in the Content element or in the itemoperation:Data element ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.39.2).
[In Elements] The Country (section 2.2.2.19) element specifies the country in which an event occurs.
[In Elements] The Data (section 2.2.2.20) element specifies the data associated with an item's Body element or BodyPart element.
[In Elements] The Data (section 2.2.2.20) element specifies the data associated with an item's BodyPart element.
[In Elements] The Delete (section 2.2.2.21) element deletes an attachment from a calendar item or from a draft email item.
[In Elements] The DisplayName (section 2.2.2.22) element specifies the display name of an attachment or the display name of an event's location.
[In Elements] The EstimatedDataSize (section 2.2.2.23) element specifies an informational estimate of the size of the data associated with the item's Body element.
[In Elements] The EstimatedDataSize (section 2.2.2.23) element specifies an informational estimate of the size of the data associated with the item's BodyPart element.
[In Elements] The EstimatedDataSize (section 2.2.2.23) element specifies an informational estimate of the size of the data associated with the attachment.
[In Elements] The FileReference (section 2.2.2.24) element specifies a unique identifier that is assigned by the server to each attachment to a message.
[In Elements] The InstanceId (section 2.2.2.25) element specifies the original, unmodified, UTC date and time of a particular instance of a recurring series.
[In Elements] The IsInline (section 2.2.2.26) element specifies whether the attachment is embedded in the message.
[In Elements] The latitude (section 2.2.2.27) element specifies the latitude of the event's location.
[In Elements] The Location (section 2.2.2.28) element specifies details about the location of an event.
[In Elements] The LocationUri (section 2.2.2.29) element specifies the URI for the location of an event.
[In Elements] The Longitude (section 2.2.2.30) element specifies the longitude of the event's location.
[In Elements] The Method (section 2.2.2.31) element identifies the method in which the attachment was attached.
[In Elements] The NativeBodyType (section 2.2.2.32) element specifies the original format type of the item.
[In Elements] The Part (section 2.2.2.33) element specifies the integer index into the metadata of the multipart response.
[In Elements] The PostalCode (section 2.2.2.34) element specifies the postal code for the address of the event's location.
[In Elements] The Preview (section 2.2.2.35) element specifies the preferred length of the message preview to be returned to the client.
[In Elements] The State (section 2.2.2.36) element specifies the state or province in which an event occurs.
[In Elements] The Status (section 2.2.2.37) element specifies the status of the Data element within the BodyPart response.
[In Elements] The Street (section 2.2.2.38) element specifies the street address of the event's location.
[In Elements] The Truncated (section 2.2.2.39) element specifies whether the body of the item has been truncated according to the BodyPreference element indicated by the client.
[In Elements] The Truncated (section 2.2.2.39) element specifies whether the body of the item has been truncated according to the BodyPartPreference element indicated by the client.
[In Elements] The TruncationSize (section 2.2.2.40) element specifies the size, in bytes, of the content that the client wants to search, synchronize, or fetch.
[In Elements] The Type (section 2.2.2.41) element specifies the format type of the body part content of the item.

[In Accuracy] The Accuracy element is an optional child element of the Location element (section 2.2.2.28) that specifies the accuracy of the values of the Latitude element (section 2.2.2.27) and the Longitude element (section 2.2.2.30).
[In Accuracy] The Accuracy element is a double data type, as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.4.
[In Accuracy] Protocol version 12.1 does not support this [Accuracy] element.
[In Accuracy] Protocol version 14.0 does not support this [Accuracy] element.
[In Accuracy] Protocol version 14.1 does not support this [Accuracy] element.
[In Accuracy] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Accuracy] element.
[In Accuracy] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Accuracy] element.
[In Add] The Add element is an optional child element of the Attachments element (section 2.2.2.8) that adds an attachment to a calendar item or to a draft email item.
[In Add] The Add element is a container data type, as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2.
[In Add] It [The Add element] has the following child elements: [ClientId, Content, ContentId, ContentLocation, ContentType, DisplayName, IsInline, Method]
[In Add] ClientId (section 2.2.2.14) — This element is required.
[In Add] Content (section 2.2.2.15) — This element is required.
[In Add] ContentId (section 2.2.2.16.1) — This element is optional.
[In Add] ContentLocation (section 2.2.2.17.1) — This element is optional.
[In Add] ContentType (section 2.2.2.18.1) — This element is optional.
[In Add] DisplayName (section 2.2.2.22.1) — This element is required.
[In Add] IsInline (section 2.2.2.26.1) — This element is optional.
[In Add] Method (section 2.2.2.31.1) — This element is required.
[In Add] Protocol version 12.1 does not support this [Add] element.
[In Add] Protocol version 14.0 does not support this [Add] element.
[In Add] Protocol version 14.1 does not support this [Add] element.
[In Add] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Add] element.
[In Add] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Add] element.

[In AllOrNone] The AllOrNone element is a child element of the BodyPartPreference element (section 2.2.2.11) and the BodyPreference element (section 2.2.2.12) that specifies whether to search, synchronize, or retrieve all or none of the content based on the TruncationSize element (section 2.2.2.40).
[In AllOrNone] The value of this element [The AllOrNone element] is a boolean value ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.1).
[In AllOrNone] When the value [of the AllOrNone element] is set to 1 (TRUE) and the content has not been truncated, all of the content is searched.
[In AllOrNone] When the value [of the AllOrNone element] is set to 1 (TRUE) and the content has not been truncated, all of the content is synchronized.
[In AllOrNone] When the value [of the AllOrNone element] is set to 1 (TRUE) and the content has not been truncated, all of the content is retrieved.
[In AllOrNone] When the value is set to 1 (TRUE) and the content has been truncated, the content is not searched.
[In AllOrNone] When the value is set to 1 (TRUE) and the content has been truncated, the content is not synchronized.
[In AllOrNone] When the value is set to 1 (TRUE) and the content has been truncated, the content is not retrieved.
[In AllOrNone] When the value is set to 0 (FALSE), the truncated is searched.
[In AllOrNone] When the value is set to 0 (FALSE), the truncated is synchronized.
[In AllOrNone] When the value is set to 0 (FALSE), the truncated is retrieved.
[In AllOrNone] When the value is set to 0 (FALSE), the nontruncated content is searched.
[In AllOrNone] When the value is set to 0 (FALSE), the nontruncated content is synchronized.
[In AllOrNone] When the value is set to 0 (FALSE), the nontruncated content is retrieved.
[In AllOrNone (BodyPartPreference)] The AllOrNone element is an optional child element of the BodyPartPreference element (section 2.2.2.11).
[In AllOrNone (BodyPartPreference)] A command request MUST have a maximum of 1 AllOrNone element per BodyPartPreference element.
[In AllOrNone (BodyPartPreference)] If the AllOrNone element is not included in the request, the truncated searched as if the value was set to 0 (FALSE).
[In AllOrNone (BodyPartPreference)] If the AllOrNone element is not included in the request, the truncated synchronized as if the value was set to 0 (FALSE).
[In AllOrNone (BodyPartPreference)] If the AllOrNone element is not included in the request, the truncated retrieved as if the value was set to 0 (FALSE).
[In AllOrNone (BodyPartPreference)] If the AllOrNone element is not included in the request, the nontruncated content is searched as if the value was set to 0 (FALSE).
[In AllOrNone (BodyPartPreference)] If the AllOrNone element is not included in the request, the nontruncated content is synchronized as if the value was set to 0 (FALSE).
[In AllOrNone (BodyPartPreference)] If the AllOrNone element is not included in the request, the nontruncated content is retrieved as if the value was set to 0 (FALSE).
[In AllOrNone (BodyPartPreference)] The AllOrNone element MUST NOT be used in command responses.
[In AllOrNone (BodyPartPreference)] This element [The AllOrNone element] MUST be ignored if the TruncationSize element is not included.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Partially verified by derived requirement: MS-ASAIRS_R400.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In AllOrNone (BodyPartPreference)] If the TruncationSize element is not included, the server will return the same response no matter whether AllOrNone is true or false.
[In AllOrNone (BodyPartPreference)] A client can include multiple BodyPartPreference elements in a command request with different values for the Type element (section 2.2.2.41.3).

[In AllOrNone (BodyPartPreference)] [A client can include multiple BodyPartPreference elements in a command request with different values for the Type element] By default, the server returns the data truncated to the size requested by TruncationSize for the Type element that matches the native storage format of the item's Body element (section 2.2.2.9).

[In AllOrNone (BodyPartPreference)] But, if the client also includes the AllOrNone element with a value of 1 (TRUE) along with the TruncationSize element, it is instructing the server not to return a truncated response for that type when the size (in bytes) of the available data exceeds the value of the TruncationSize element.
[In AllOrNone (BodyPartPreference)] For example, a client can use these two elements to signify that it cannot process partial Rich Text Format (RTF) data (a Type element value of 3).

[In AllOrNone (BodyPartPreference)] In this case[if the client also includes the AllOrNone element with a value of 1 (TRUE) along with the TruncationSize element, it is instructing the server not to return a truncated response for that type when the size (in bytes) of the available data exceeds the value of the TruncationSize element], if the client has specified multiple BodyPartPreference elements, the server selects the next BodyPartPreference element that will return the maximum amount of body text to the client.

Assume that the client specifies two BodyPartPreference elements: <airsyncbase:BodyPartPreference> <airsyncbase:Type>2</airsyncbase:Type> <airsyncbase:AllOrNone>1</airsyncbase:AllOrNone> <airsyncbase:TruncationSize>50</airsyncbase:TruncationSize> </airsyncbase:BodyPartPreference>
<airsyncbase:BodyPartPreference> <airsyncbase:Type>1</airsyncbase:Type> <airsyncbase:TruncationSize>50</airsyncbase:TruncationSize> </airsyncbase:BodyPartPreference> The first BodyPartPreference element requests an HTML body, but only if the body size is less than 50 bytes. The second requests an element in plain text format.

Assume that the client specifies two BodyPartPreference elements: <airsyncbase:BodyPartPreference> <airsyncbase:Type>2</airsyncbase:Type> <airsyncbase:AllOrNone>1</airsyncbase:AllOrNone> <airsyncbase:TruncationSize>50</airsyncbase:TruncationSize> </airsyncbase:BodyPartPreference>
<airsyncbase:BodyPartPreference> <airsyncbase:Type>1</airsyncbase:Type> <airsyncbase:TruncationSize>50</airsyncbase:TruncationSize> </airsyncbase:BodyPartPreference> If the client requests a text body whose native format is HTML, and the size of the data exceeds 50 bytes, the server converts the body to plain text and returns the first 50 bytes of plain text data.
[In AllOrNone (BodyPartPreference)] Protocol version 12.1 does not support this [AllOrNone (BodyPartPreference)] element.
[In AllOrNone (BodyPartPreference)] Protocol version 14.0 does not support this [AllOrNone (BodyPartPreference)] element.
[In AllOrNone (BodyPartPreference)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [AllOrNone (BodyPartPreference)] element.
[In AllOrNone (BodyPartPreference)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [AllOrNone (BodyPartPreference)] element.
[In AllOrNone (BodyPartPreference)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [AllOrNone (BodyPartPreference)] element.
[In AllOrNone (BodyPreference)] The AllOrNone element is an optional child element of the BodyPreference element (section 2.2.2.7).
[In AllOrNone (BodyPreference)] A command request MUST have a maximum of 1 AllOrNone element per BodyPreference element.
[In AllOrNone (BodyPreference)] If the AllOrNone element is not included in the request, then the truncated content is searched as if the value was set to 0 (FALSE).
[In AllOrNone (BodyPreference)] If the AllOrNone element is not included in the request, then the truncated content is synchronized as if the value was set to 0 (FALSE).
[In AllOrNone (BodyPreference)] If the AllOrNone element is not included in the request, then the truncated content is retrieved as if the value was set to 0 (FALSE).
[In AllOrNone (BodyPreference)] If the AllOrNone element is not included in the request, then the non-truncated content is searched as if the value was set to 0 (FALSE).
[In AllOrNone (BodyPreference)] If the AllOrNone element is not included in the request, then the non-truncated content is synchronized as if the value was set to 0 (FALSE).
[In AllOrNone (BodyPreference)] If the AllOrNone element is not included in the request, then the non-truncated content is retrieved as if the value was set to 0 (FALSE).
[In AllOrNone (BodyPreference)] The AllOrNone element MUST NOT be used in command responses.
[In AllOrNone (BodyPreference)] This element [The AllOrNone element] MUST be ignored if the TruncationSize element is not included.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Partially verified by derived requirement: MS-ASAIRS_R401.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In AllOrNone (BodyPreference)]If the TruncationSize element is not included, the server will return the same response no matter whether AllOrNone is true or false.
[In AllOrNone (BodyPreference)] A client can include multiple BodyPreference elements in a command request with different values for the Type element (section 2.2.2.41.4).

[In AllOrNone (BodyPreference)] [A client can include multiple BodyPreference elements in a command request with different values for the Type element] By default, the server returns the data truncated to the size requested by TruncationSize for the Type element that matches the native storage format of the item's Body element (section 2.2.2.9).

[In AllOrNone (BodyPreference)] But, if the client also includes the AllOrNone element with a value of 1 (TRUE) along with the TruncationSize element, it is instructing the server not to return a truncated response for that type when the size (in bytes) of the available data exceeds the value of the TruncationSize element.
[In AllOrNone (BodyPreference)] For example, a client can use these two elements to signify that it cannot process partial Rich Text Format (RTF) data (a Type element value of 3).

[In AllOrNone (BodyPreference)] In this case [if the client also includes the AllOrNone element with a value of 1 (TRUE) along with the TruncationSize element, it is instructing the server not to return a truncated response for that type when the size (in bytes) of the available data exceeds the value of the TruncationSize element], if the client has specified multiple BodyPreference elements, the server selects the next BodyPreference element that will return the maximum amount of body text to the client.

[In AllOrNone] Assume that the client specifies two BodyPreference elements. <airsyncbase:BodyPreference> <airsyncbase:Type>2</airsyncbase:Type> <airsyncbase:AllOrNone>1</airsyncbase:AllOrNone> <airsyncbase:TruncationSize>50</airsyncbase:TruncationSize> </airsyncbase:BodyPreference>
<airsyncbase:BodyPreference> <airsyncbase:Type>1</airsyncbase:Type> <airsyncbase:TruncationSize>50</airsyncbase:TruncationSize> </airsyncbase:BodyPreference> The first BodyPreference element requests an HTML body, but only if the body size is less than 50 bytes. The second requests an element in plain text format.

[In AllOrNone] Assume that the client specifies two BodyPreference elements. <airsyncbase:BodyPreference> <airsyncbase:Type>2</airsyncbase:Type> <airsyncbase:AllOrNone>1</airsyncbase:AllOrNone> <airsyncbase:TruncationSize>50</airsyncbase:TruncationSize> </airsyncbase:BodyPreference>
<airsyncbase:BodyPreference> <airsyncbase:Type>1</airsyncbase:Type> <airsyncbase:TruncationSize>50</airsyncbase:TruncationSize> </airsyncbase:BodyPreference> If the client requests a text body whose native format is HTML, and the size of the data exceeds 50 bytes, the server converts the body to plain text and returns the first 50 bytes of plain text data.
[In AllOrNone (BodyPreference)] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [AllOrNone (BodyPreference)] element.
[In AllOrNone (BodyPreference)] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [AllOrNone (BodyPreference)] element.
[In AllOrNone (BodyPreference)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [AllOrNone (BodyPreference)] element.
[In AllOrNone (BodyPreference)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [AllOrNone (BodyPreference)] element.
[In AllOrNone (BodyPreference)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [AllOrNone (BodyPreference)] element.
[In Altitude] The Altitude element is an optional child element of the Location element (section 2.2.2.28) that specifies the altitude of an event's location.
[In Altitude] The altitude is measured in meters above the WGS-84 ellipsoid, which is described in [NGA-WGS84].
[In Altitude] The Altitude element is a double data type, as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.4.
[In Altitude] Protocol version 12.1 does not support this [Altitude] element.
[In Altitude] Protocol version 14.0 does not support this [Altitude] element.
[In Altitude] Protocol version 14.1 does not support this [Altitude] element.
[In Altitude] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Altitude] element.
[In Altitude] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Altitude] element.

[In AltitudeAccuracy] The AltitudeAccuracy element is an optional child element of the Location element (section 2.2.2.28) that specifies the accuracy of the value of the Altitude element (section 2.2.2.4).
[In AltitudeAccuracy] The AltitudeAccuracy element is a double data type, as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.4.
[In AltitudeAccuracy] Protocol version 12.1 does not support this [AltitudeAccuracy] element.
[In AltitudeAccuracy] Protocol version 14.0 does not support this [AltitudeAccuracy] element.
[In AltitudeAccuracy] Protocol version 14.1 does not support this [AltitudeAccuracy] element.
[In AltitudeAccuracy] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [AltitudeAccuracy] element.
[In AltitudeAccuracy] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [AltitudeAccuracy] element.
[In Annotation] The Annotation element is an optional child element of the Location element (section 2.2.2.28) that specifies a note about the location of an event.
[In Annotation] The Annotation element is a string data type, as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7.
[In Annotation] Protocol version 12.1 does not support this [Annotation] element.
[In Annotation] Protocol version 14.0 does not support this [Annotation] element.
[In Annotation] Protocol version 14.1 does not support this [Annotation] element.
[In Annotation] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Annotation] element.
[In Annotation] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Annotation] element.
[In Attachment] The Attachment element is a required child element of the Attachments element (section 2.2.2.8).
[In Attachment] [The Attachment element] specifies the attachment information for a single attachment item.
[In Attachment] Command requests MUST NOT include the Attachment element.
[In Attachment] The Attachment element is a container data type, as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2.

[In Attachment] The Attachment element has the following child elements[DisplayName, FileReference, Method, EstimatedDataSize, ContentId, ContentLocation, IsInline, email2:UmAttDuration, email2:UmAttOrder] in any order (elements noted as optional can be in the response):
[In Attachment] DisplayName (section 2.2.2.11). This element is optional.
[In Attachment] FileReference (section 2.2.2.24.1). This element is required.
[In Attachment] Method (section 2.2.2.31.2). This element is required.
[In Attachment] EstimatedDataSize (section 2.2.2.23.1). This element is required.
[In Attachment] ContentId (section 2.2.2.8). This element is optional.
[In Attachment] ContentLocation (section 2.2.2.9). This element is optional.
[In Attachment] IsInline (section 2.2.2.14). This element is optional.
[In Attachment] email2:UmAttDuration ([MS-ASEMAIL] section 2.2.2.69). This element is optional.
[In Attachment] email2:UmAttOrder ([MS-ASEMAIL] section 2.2.2.70). This element is optional.
[In Attachment] The Attachment element has the following child elements [ClientId], in any order, in a Sync command response with a Responses element ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.154):
[In Attachment] ClientId (section 2.2.2.14). This element is required.
[In Attachment] FileReference (section 2.2.2.24.1). This element is required.
[In Attachment] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [Attachment] element.
[In Attachment] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Attachment] element.
[In Attachment] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Attachment] element.
[In Attachment] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Attachment] element.
[In Attachment] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Attachment] element.
[In Attachment] The server returns the Attachment element in a Sync command response with a Responses element only when protocol version 16.0 is used.
[In Attachment] The server returns the Attachment element in a Sync command response with a Responses element only when protocol version 16.1 is used.

[In Attachments] The Attachments element is an optional child element of the airsync:ApplicationData element ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.11), the itemoperations:Properties element ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.139.2), and the search:Properties element ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.139.3) that contains one or more attachment items.
[In Attachments] The Attachments element is a container data type, as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2.
[In Attachments] It [The Attachments element] has the following child elements [Attachment, Add, Delete]:
[In Attachments] Attachment (section 2.2.2.7), in a Sync ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.20), ItemOperations ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.9), or Search ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.15) command response
[In Attachments] Add (section 2.2.2.2), in a Sync command request
[In Attachments] Delete (section 2.2.2.21), in a Sync command request
[In Attachments] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [Attachments] element.
[In Attachments] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Attachments] element.
[In Attachments] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Attachments] element.
[In Attachments] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Attachments] element.
[In Attachments] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Attachments] element.

[In Body] The Body element is an optional child element of the airsync:ApplicationData element ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.11), the itemoperations:Properties element ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.139.2), the search:Properties element ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.139.3), the meetingresponse:SendResponse element ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.163), and the composemail:SmartForward element ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.169) that specifies a free-form, variable-length data field associated with an item stored on the server.
[In Body] Examples[of the Body element] include, but are not limited to, the body of an e-mail message and the Notes field in a contact.
[In Body] The Body element is a container data type, as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2.
[In Body] The Body element MUST be included in a response message whenever an item has changes [or new items are created].
[In Body] The Body element MUST be included in a response message whenever [an item has changes or] new items are created.
[In Body] There is no limit on the number of Body elements in a command response.
[In Body] When included in a command response, the Body element indicates the existence of one or more variable-length fields of data associated with the item.
[In Body] Command requests can include the Body element.
[In Body] The Body element, if present, has the following required and optional child elements in this order [Type, EstimatedDataSize, Truncated, Data, Part, Preview].
[In Body] Type (section 2.2.2.41.1): This element is required.
[In Body] EstimatedDataSize (section 2.2.2.12.2): This element is optional.
[In Body] Truncated (section 2.2.2.39.1):This element is optional.

[In BodyPart] The BodyPart element is an optional child element of the airsync:ApplicationData element that specifies details about the message part of an e-mail in a response.
[In BodyPart] The BodyPart element MUST be included in a command response when the BodyPartPreference element (section 2.2.2.11) is specified in a request.
[In BodyPart] The BodyPart element is a container data type, as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2.
[In BodyPart] There is no limit on the number of BodyPart elements in a command response.
[In BodyPart] Command requests MUST NOT include the BodyPart element.
[In BodyPart] In a response, the airsync:ApplicationData element MUST be the parent element of the BodyPart element.
[In BodyPart] The BodyPart element, if present, MUST have its required and optional child elements in the following order [Status, Type, EstimatedDataSize, Truncated, Data, Preview].
[In BodyPart] Status (section 2.2.2.37). This element is required.
[In BodyPart] Type (section 2.2.2.41.2). This element is required.
[In BodyPart] EstimatedDataSize (section 2.2.2.23.3). This element is required.

[In BodyPartPreference] The BodyPartPreference element is an optional element that sets preference information related to the type and size of information that is returned from searching, synchronizing, or fetching a message part.
[In BodyPartPreference] The BodyPartPreference element is a container data type, as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2.
[In BodyPartPreference] A command response MUST NOT include a BodyPartPreference element.
[In BodyPartPreference] Command requests can include the BodyPartPreference element.
[In BodyPartPreference] The Options element ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.125) MUST be the parent element of the BodyPartPreference element.
[In BodyPartPreference] The BodyPartPreference element, if present, MUST have the following required and optional child elements in the following order [Type, TruncationSize, AllOrNone, Preview].
[In BodyPartPreference] Type (section 2.2.2.41.3). This element is required.
[In BodyPartPreference] TruncationSize (section 2.2.2.21.1). This element is optional.
[In BodyPartPreference] AllOrNone (section 2.2.2.1.1). This element is optional.
[In BodyPartPreference] Preview (section 2.2.2.18.3). This element is optional.
[In BodyPartPreference] The contents of the Options element specify preferences for all of the content that the user is interested in searching, synchronizing, or retrieving.
[In BodyPartPreference] These preferences are set on a per-request basis and override any stored information.
[In BodyPartPreference] Because this information is required to process every request, the information can be persisted on the server if network load is a concern.

[In BodyPartPreference] There MUST be one explicit BodyPartPreference element for each Type value specified in the set of preferences in order to request a BodyPart element (section 2.2.2.10) of that Type in the response.
[In BodyPartPreference] Protocol version 12.1 does not support this [BodyPartPreference] element.

[In BodyPreference] The contents of the airsync:Options, itemoperations:Options, or search:Options element specify preferences for all of the content that the user is interested in searching, synchronizing, or retrieving.

[In BodyPreference] These preferences [preferences for all of the content that the user is interested in searching, synchronizing, or retrieving] are persisted by the server from request to request for the specified client, and can be changed by the inclusion of an airsync:Options element in any subsequent request.
[In BodyPreference] A request MUST NOT contain more than one BodyPreference element for each allowable value of the Type element.

[In ClientId] The ClientId element is a string data type, as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7.

[In Data] The Data element is a child element of the Body element (section 2.2.2.4) and the BodyPart element (section 2.2.2.5) that contains the data of the message body (2) or the message part of the calendar item, contact, document, e-mail, or task.
[In Data] The value of this element [the Data element] is a string data type, as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7.
[In Data (Body)] The Data element is an optional child element of the Body element (section 2.2.2.4).
[In Data (Body)] A command response MUST have a maximum of one Data element within each returned Body element.
[In Data (Body)] Command requests can include the Data element.
[In Data (Body)] This element [the Data (Body) element] MUST NOT be present in multipart responses, as specified in [MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.10.1.
[In Data (Body)] The content of the Data element is returned as a string in the format that is specified by the Type element (section 2.2.2.41.1).
[In Data (Body)] If the value of the Type element is 3 (RTF), the value of the Data element is encoded using base64 encoding.
[In Data (Body)] If the Truncated element (section 2.2.2.39.1) is included in the response, the data in the Data element is truncated.
[In Data (Body)] The EstimatedDataSize element (section 2.2.2.23.2) provides a rough estimation of the actual size of the complete content of the Data string.

[In EstimatedDataSize] The EstimatedDataSize element is a child element of the Attachment element (section 2.2.2.2), the Body element (section 2.2.2.4), and the BodyPart element (section 2.2.2.5) that provides an informational estimate of the size of the data associated with the parent element.
[In EstimatedDataSize] The value of this element [the EstimatedDataSize element] is an integer value ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.6).
[In EstimatedDataSize] The EstimatedDataSize value represents an estimate of the original size of the content in the message store and is specified in bytes.
[In EstimatedDataSize] This number is only an estimate, and the actual size of the content when fetched can differ based on the content filtering rules applied.
[In EstimatedDataSize (Attachment)] The EstimatedDataSize element is required child element of the Attachment element (section 2.2.2.7).
[In EstimatedDataSize (Attachment)] A command response MUST have a maximum of one EstimatedDataSize element per Attachment element.
[In EstimatedDataSize (Attachment)] The EstimatedDataSize element MUST have no child elements.

[In EstimatedDataSize (Body)] The EstimatedDataSize element is an optional child element of the Body element (section 2.2.2.9).
[In EstimatedDataSize (Body)] The EstimatedDataSize element SHOULD be included in a response message whenever the Truncated element is set to TRUE.

[In FileReference (Attachment)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [FileReference (Attachment)] element.
[In FileReference (Attachment)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [FileReference (Attachment)] element.

[In FileReference (Attachment)] In protocol version 16.0, the server will return the FileReference element along with the ClientId element (section 2.2.2.14) as child elements of the Attachment element in response to a Sync command request ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.20) that adds an attachment [either] to a calendar item [or to a draft email item].

In protocol version 16.0, the server will return the FileReference element along with the ClientId element (section 2.2.2.14) as child elements of the Attachment element in response to a Sync command request ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.1.21) that adds an attachment either to a calendar item or to a draft email item.

In protocol version 16.1, the server will return the FileReference element along with the ClientId element (section 2.2.2.14) as child elements of the Attachment element in response to a Sync command request ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.1.21) that adds an attachment either to a calendar item or to a draft email item.
[In FileReference (Attachment)] The client MUST record the value of the FileReference element that is returned.
[In FileReference (Attachment)] This value will be used to specify the attachment in a future Sync command request if the client deletes the attachment.

[In FileReference (Delete)] The FileReference element is a required child element of the Delete element (section 2.2.2.21) that specifies the server-assigned unique identifier of the attachment to be deleted.
[In FileReference (Delete)] The FileReference element is a string data type, as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7.
[In FileReference (Delete)]] A unique identifer is assigned to the attachment when the attachment is added.
[In FileReference (Delete)]] This identifier is returned to the client in the FileReference element of the Sync command response, as specified in section 2.2.2.24.1.
[In FileReference (Delete)]] To specify a particular attachment for deletion, the client uses the same identifier that was returned in the FileReference element when the attachment was added.
[In FileReference (Delete)] Protocol version 12.1 does not support this [FileReference (Delete)] element.
[In FileReference (Delete)] Protocol version 14.0 does not support this [FileReference (Delete)] element.
[In FileReference (Delete)] Protocol version 14.1 does not support this [FileReference (Delete)] element.
[In FileReference (Delete)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [FileReference (Delete)] element.
[In FileReference (Delete)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [FileReference (Delete)] element.
[In FileReference (Delete)] The FileReference element is not supported as a child of the Delete element in protocol versions 2.5, 12.0, 12.1, 14.0, and 14.1.

[In FileReference (Fetch)] In an ItemOperations command request (as specified in [MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.8), the FileReference element is an optional child element of the itemoperations:Fetch element (as specified in [MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.63.1).
[In FileReference (Fetch)] The FileReference element specifies a unique identifier that is assigned by the server to each Attachment object to a Message object.
[In FileReference (Fetch)] The FileReference element is a string data type, as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7.

[In FileReference (Fetch)] If the client includes a zero-length string for the value of this element [the FileReference (Fetch) element] in an ItemOperations command request, the server responds with a protocol status error of 15.
[In FileReference (Fetch)] The FileReference element MUST have no child elements.
[In FileReference (Fetch)] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [FileReference (Fetch)] element.
[In FileReference (Fetch)] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [FileReference (Fetch)] element.
[In FileReference (Fetch)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [FileReference (Fetch)] element.
[In FileReference (Fetch)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [FileReference (Fetch)] element.
[In FileReference (Fetch)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [FileReference (Fetch)] element.
[In InstanceId] The InstanceId element specifies the original, unmodified, UTC date and time of a particular instance of a recurring series.

[In InstanceId] The InstanceId element is a child element of the calendar:Exception element ([MS-ASCAL] section 2.2.2.21) in a Sync command request and response ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.1.21) and a child element of the airsync:ApplicationData element ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.11) in a Sync command response for an orphan instance.

[In InstanceId] The InstanceId element is a child element of the airsync:Change element ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.24) or the airsync:Delete element ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.42.2) in a Sync command request.
[In InstanceId] The server will include the InstanceId element along with the ServerId element ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.166.8) in any Sync command response to the client's Sync command request.
[In InstanceId] The value of this element is a string data type, as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7.
[In InstanceId] The string MUST be formatted as a Compact DateTime, as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7.5.
[In InstanceId] Protocol version 12.1 does not support this [InstanceId] element.
[In InstanceId] Protocol version 14.0 does not support this [InstanceId] element.
[In InstanceId] Protocol version 14.1 does not support this [InstanceId] element.
[In InstanceId] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [InstanceId] element.
[In InstanceId] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [InstanceId] element.
[In IsInline] The IsInline element is a child element of the Add element (section 2.2.2.2) and the Attachment element (section 2.2.2.7).
[In IsInline] For more details about the IsInline element, see sections 2.2.2.25.1 and 2.2.2.25.2.
[In IsInline (Add)] The IsInline element is an optional child element of the Add element (section 2.2.2.2) that indicates whether the attachment being added is embedded in the message.
[In IsInline (Add)] The IsInline element is an empty tag element, meaning it has no value or data type.
[In IsInline (Add)] It is distinguished only by the presence or absence of the <IsInline/> tag.
[In IsInline (Add)] Presence of the tag indicates that the attachment is embedded in the message[; absence indicates that the attachment is not embedded].
[In IsInline (Add)] [Presence of the tag indicates that the attachment is embedded in the message;] absence indicates that the attachment is not embedded.
[In IsInline (Add)] The Add element MUST have a maximum of one IsInline element.
[In IsInline (Add)] Protocol version 12.1 does not support this [IsInline (Add)] element.
[In IsInline (Add)] Protocol version 14.0 does not support this [IsInline (Add)] element.
[In IsInline (Add)] Protocol version 14.1 does not support this [IsInline (Add)] element.
[In IsInline (Add)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [IsInline (Add)] element.
[In IsInline (Add)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [IsInline (Add)] element.
[In IsInline (Attachment)] The IsInline element is an optional child element of the Attachment element (section 2.2.2.7).
[In IsInline (Attachment)] [The IsInline element] specifies whether the attachment is embedded in the message.
[In IsInline (Attachment)] If the value[IsInline] is TRUE, then the attachment is embedded in the message.
[In IsInline (Attachment)] If the value[IsInline] is FALSE, then the attachment is not embedded in the message.
[In IsInline (Attachment)] The value of this element [the IsInline element] is a boolean value ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.1).
[In IsInline (Attachment)] A command response MUST have a maximum of one IsInline element per Attachment element.
[In IsInline (Attachment)] The IsInline element MUST have no child elements.
[In IsInline (Attachment)] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [IsInline (Attachment)] element.
[In IsInline (Attachment)] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [IsInline (Attachment)] element.
[In IsInline (Attachment)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [IsInline (Attachment)] element.
[In IsInline (Attachment)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [IsInline (Attachment)] element.
[In IsInline (Attachment)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [IsInline (Attachment)] element.
[In Latitude] The Latitude element is an optional child element of the Location element (section 2.2.2.28) that specifies the latitude of the event's location.
[In Latitude] The Latitude element is a double data type, as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.4.
[In Latitude] Protocol version 12.1 does not support this [Latitude] element.
[In Latitude] Protocol version 14.0 does not support this [Latitude] element.
[In Latitude] Protocol version 14.1 does not support this [Latitude] element.
[In Latitude] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Latitude] element.
[In Latitude] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Latitude] element.
[In Location] The Location element specifies details about the location of an event.

[In Location] This element is an optional child element of the following elements [airsync:ApplicationData, itemoperations:Schema, itemoperations:Properties, search:Properties, calendar:Exception, email:MeetingRequest]:
[In Location] airsync:ApplicationData ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.11), in a command request or a command response
[In Location] itemoperations:Schema ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.158), in a command request
[In Location] itemoperations:Properties ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.139.2), in a command response
[In Location] search:Properties ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.139.3), in a command response
[In Location] calendar:Exception ([MS-ASCAL] section 2.2.2.21), in a command request or a command response
[In Location] email:MeetingRequest ([MS-ASEMAIL] section 2.2.2.48), in a command request or a command response
[In Location] The Location element is container data type, as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2.
[In Location] The client's request can include an empty Location element to remove the location from an item.

[In Location] The Location element has the following child elements [Accuracy, Altitude, AltitudeAccuracy, Annotation, City, Country, DisplayName, Latitude, LocationUri, Longitude, PostalCode, State, Street], all of which are optional:
[In Location] Accuracy (section 2.2.2.1)
[In Location] Altitude (section 2.2.2.4)
[In Location] AltitudeAccuracy (section 2.2.2.5)
[In Location] Annotation (section 2.2.2.6)
[In Location] City (section 2.2.2.13)
[In Location] Country (section 2.2.2.19)
[In Location] DisplayName (section 2.2.2.22.3)
[In Location] Latitude (section 2.2.2.26)
[In Location] LocationUri (section 2.2.2.29)
[In Location] Longitude (section 2.2.2.30)
[In Location] PostalCode (section 2.2.2.34)
[In Location] State (section 2.2.2.36)
[In Location] Street (section 2.2.2.38)
[In Location] Protocol version 12.1 does not support this [Location] element.
[In Location] Protocol version 14.0 does not support this [Location] element.
[In Location] Protocol version 14.1 does not support this [Location] element.
[In Location] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Location] element.
[In Location] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Location] element.

[In Location] The calendar:Location element, as specified in [MS-ASCAL] section 2.2.2.26, and the email:Location element, as specified in [MS-ASEMAIL] section 2.2.2.44, are used with protocol versions 2.5, 12.0, 12.1, 14.0, and 14.1 instead of the Location element of the AirSyncBase namespace.
[In LocationUri] The LocationUri element is an optional child element of the Location element (section 2.2.2.28) that specifies the URI for the location of an event.
[In LocationUri] The LocationUri element is a string data type, as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7.
[In LocationUri] Protocol version 12.1 does not support this [LocationUri] element.
[In LocationUri] Protocol version 14.0 does not support this [LocationUri] element.
[In LocationUri] Protocol version 14.1 does not support this [LocationUri] element.
[In LocationUri] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [LocationUri] element.
[In LocationUri] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [LocationUri] element.
[In Longitude] The Longitude element is an optional child element of the Location element (section 2.2.2.28) that specifies the longitude of the event's location.
[In Longitude] The Longitude element is a double data type, as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.4.
[In Longitude] Protocol version 12.1 does not support this [Longitude] element.
[In Longitude] Protocol version 14.0 does not support this [Longitude] element.
[In Longitude] Protocol version 14.1 does not support this [Longitude] element.
[In Longitude] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Longitude] element.
[In Longitude] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Longitude] element.
[In Method] The Method element is a child element of the Add element (section 2.2.2.2) and the Attachment element (section 2.2.2.7).
[In Method] For more details about the Method element, see sections 2.2.2.31.1 and 2.2.2.31.2.
[In Method (Add)] The Method element is a required child element of the Add element (section 2.2.2.2) that identifies the method in which the attachment to be added was attached.
[In Method (Add)] The Method element is an unsignedByte data type, as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.8.
[In Method (Add)] The Add element MUST have a maximum of one Method element.
[In Method (Add)] The following table lists the possible values [1, 5] of the Method element as a child element of the Add element.
[In Method (Add)] [The value] 1 [of the Method element] meaning "Normal attachment" specifies that the attachment is a normal attachment.
[In Method (Add)] [The value] 1 [of the Method element] meaning "Normal attachment" is valid for a calendar item [or a draft email item].
[In Method (Add)] [The value] 1 [of the Method element] meaning "Normal attachment" is valid for [a calendar item or] a draft email item.
[In Method (Add)] [The value] 5 [of the Method element] meaning "Embedded message" is an email message and the attachment file has an .eml extension.
[In Method (Add)] [The value] 5 [of the Method element] meaning "Embedded message" is valid only for a draft email item.
[In Method (Add)] Protocol version 12.1 does not support this [Method (Add)] element.
[In Method (Add)] Protocol version 14.0 does not support this [Method (Add)] element.
[In Method (Add)] Protocol version 14.1 does not support this [Method (Add)] element.
[In Method (Add)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Method (Add)] element.
[In Method (Add)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Method (Add)] element.
[In Method (Attachment)] The Method element is a required child element of the Attachment element (section 2.2.2.7) that identifies the method in which the attachment was attached.
[In Method (Attachment)] The value of this element [the Method element] is an unsignedByte value ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.8).
[In Method (Attachment)] A command response MUST have a maximum of one Method element per Attachment element.
[In Method (Attachment)] The Method element MUST have no child elements.
[In Method (Attachment)] The following table defines the valid values [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6] of the Method element.
[In Method (Attachment)] [The value] 1 [of the Method element] meaning "Normal attachment" specifies that the attachment is a normal attachment.
[In Method (Attachment)] [The value] 1 [of the Method element] meaning "Normal attachment" is the most common value.
[In Method (Attachment)] [The value] 2 [of the Method element] meaning "Reserved" and do not use.
[In Method (Attachment)] [The value] 3 [of the Method element] meaning "Reserved" and do not use.
[In Method (Attachment)] [The value] 4 [of the Method element] meaning "Reserved" and do not use.
[In Method (Attachment)] [The value] 5 [of the Method element] meaning "Embedded message" indicates that the attachment is an e-mail message, and that the attachment file has an .eml extension.
[In Method (Attachment)] [The value] 6 [of the Method element] meaning "Attach OLE" indicates that the attachment is an embedded Object Linking and Embedding (OLE) object, such as an inline image.
[In Method (Attachment)] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [Method (Attachment)] element.
[In Method (Attachment)] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Method (Attachment)] element.
[In Method (Attachment)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Method (Attachment)] element.
[In Method (Attachment)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Method (Attachment)] element.
[In Method (Attachment)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Method (Attachment)] element.

[In NativeBodyType] The NativeBodyType element is an optional child element of the airsync:ApplicationData element ([MS-ASCMD]) in the Sync command that specifies the original format type of the item.
[In NativeBodyType] The value of this element [the NativeBodyType element] is an unsignedByte value ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.8).
[In NativeBodyType] A command response MUST have a maximum of one NativeBodyType element per airsync:ApplicationData element.
[In NativeBodyType] Command requests can include the NativeBodyType element.
[In NativeBodyType] The NativeBodyType element MUST have no child elements.
[In NativeBodyType] The following table defines the valid values [1, 2, 3] of the NativeBodyType enumeration.
[In NativeBodyType] [The value] 1 represents Plain text.
[In NativeBodyType] [The value] 2 represents HTML.
[In NativeBodyType] [The value] 3 represents RTF.
[In NativeBodyType] The NativeBodyType and Type elements have the same value unless the server has modified the format of the body to match the client's request.
[In NativeBodyType] The NativeBodyType and Type elements have the same value if the server has not modified the format of the body to match the client's request.
[In NativeBodyType] The NativeBodyType and Type elements have different values if the server has modified the format of the body to match the client's request.
[In NativeBodyType] The client can specify a preferred body format by using the Type element of a Search or Sync command request.
[In NativeBodyType] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [NativeBodyType] element.
[In NativeBodyType] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [NativeBodyType] element.
[In NativeBodyType] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [NativeBodyType] element.
[In NativeBodyType] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [NativeBodyType] element.
[In NativeBodyType] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [NativeBodyType] element.

[In Part] The Part element ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.130) is an optional child element of the Body element (section 2.2.2.4) that contains an integer index into the metadata of the multipart response.
[In Part] This element [the Part element] MUST be present in multipart responses, as specified in [MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.9.1.
[In Part] This element [the Part element] MUST NOT be present in requests.
[In Part] This element MUST NOT be present in non-multipart responses.
[In Part] The value of this element [the Part element] is an integer ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.6).
[In Part] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [Part] element.
[In Part] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Part] element.
[In Part] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Part] element.
[In Part] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Part] element.
[In Part] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Part] element.
[In PostalCode] The PostalCode element is an optional child element of the Location element (section 2.2.2.28) that specifies the postal code for the address of the event's location.
[In PostalCode] The PostalCode element is a string data type, as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7.
[In PostalCode] Protocol version 12.1 does not support this [PostalCode] element.
[In PostalCode] Protocol version 14.0 does not support this [PostalCode] element.
[In PostalCode] Protocol version 14.1 does not support this [PostalCode] element.
[In PostalCode] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [PostalCode] element.
[In PostalCode] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [PostalCode] element.

[In Preview] The Preview element is a child element of the Body element (section 2.2.2.4), the BodyPart element (section 2.2.2.5), the BodyPartPreference element (section 2.2.2.6), and the BodyPreference element (section 2.2.2.6).
[In Preview (Body)] The Preview element is an optional child element of the Body element (section 2.2.2.9) that contains the Unicode plain text message or message part preview returned to the client.
[In Preview (Body)] The value of this element [the Preview element] is a string ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7).
[In Preview (Body)] The Preview element in a response MUST contain no more than the number of characters specified in the request.
[In Preview (Body)] Command responses MUST have a maximum of one Preview element per Body element.

[In Preview (Body)] If the Body element in the request contains a Type element of value 1 (Plain text) and there is valid data returned in the Data element (section 2.2.2.20.1), then the Preview element will not be returned in the same response.
[In Preview (Body)] The Preview element MUST have no child elements.
[In Preview (Body)] Protocol version 12.1 does not support this [Preview (Body)] element.
[In Preview (Body)] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Preview (Body)] element.
[In Preview (Body)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Preview (Body)] element.
[In Preview (Body)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Preview (Body)] element.
[In Preview (Body)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Preview (Body)] element.

[In Preview (BodyPart)] The Preview element is an optional child element of the BodyPart element (section 2.2.2.10) that contains the Unicode plain text message or message part preview returned to the client.
[In Preview (BodyPart)] The value of this element [the Preview element] is a string ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7).
[In Preview (BodyPart)] The Preview element in a response MUST contain no more than the number of characters specified in the request.

[In Preview (BodyPart)] The Preview element MUST be present in a command response if a BodyPartPreference element (section 2.2.2.11) in the request included a Preview element and the server can honor the request.
[In Preview (BodyPart)] Command responses MUST have a maximum of one Preview element per BodyPart element.
[In Preview (BodyPart)] The Preview element MUST have no child elements.
[In Preview (BodyPart)] Protocol version 12.1 does not support this [Preview (BodyPart)] element.
[In Preview (BodyPart)] Protocol version 14.0 does not support this [Preview (BodyPart)] element.
[In Preview (BodyPart)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Preview (BodyPart)] element.
[In Preview (BodyPart)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Preview (BodyPart)] element.
[In Preview (BodyPart)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Preview (BodyPart)] element.
[In Preview (BodyPartPreference)] The Preview element is an optional child element of the BodyPartPreference element (section 2.2.2.11).
[In Preview (BodyPartPreference)] [The Preview element] specifies the maximum length of the Unicode plain text message or message part preview to be returned to the client.
[In Preview (BodyPartPreference)] The value of this element [the BodyPartPreference element] is an integer value ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.6).
[In Preview (BodyPartPreference)] This element [the BodyPartPreference element] MUST have a value set from 0 to 255, inclusive.
[In Preview (BodyPartPreference)] A command request MUST have a maximum of one Preview element per BodyPartPreference element.
[In Preview (BodyPartPreference)] The Preview element MUST have no child elements.
[In Preview (BodyPartPreference)] Protocol version 12.1 does not support this [Preview (BodyPartPreference)] element.
[In Preview (BodyPartPreference)] Protocol version 14.0 does not support this [Preview (BodyPartPreference)] element.
[In Preview (BodyPartPreference)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Preview (BodyPartPreference)] element.
[In Preview (BodyPartPreference)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Preview (BodyPartPreference)] element.
[In Preview (BodyPartPreference)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Preview (BodyPartPreference)] element.
[In Preview (BodyPreference)] The Preview element is an optional child element of the BodyPreference element (section 2.2.2.12).
[In Preview (BodyPreference)] [The Preview element] specifies the maximum length of the Unicode plain text message or message part preview to be returned to the client.
[In Preview (BodyPreference)] The value of this element is an integer value (as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.6).
[In Preview (BodyPreference)] This element [the BodyPreference element] MUST have a value set from 0 to 255, inclusive.
[In Preview (BodyPreference)] A command request MUST have a maximum of one Preview element per BodyPreference element.
[In Preview (BodyPreference)] The Preview element MUST have no child elements.
[In Preview (BodyPreference)] Protocol version 12.1 does not support this [Preview (BodyPreference)] element.
[In Preview (BodyPreference)] Protocol version 14.0 does not support this [Preview (BodyPreference)] element.
[In Preview (BodyPreference)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Preview (BodyPreference)] element.
[In Preview (BodyPreference)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Preview (BodyPreference)] element.
[In Preview (BodyPreference)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Preview (BodyPreference)] element.
[In State] The State element is an optional child element of the Location element (section 2.2.2.27) that specifies the state or province in which an event occurs.
[In State] The State element is a string data type, as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7.
[In State] Protocol version 12.1 does not support this [State] element.
[In State] Protocol version 14.0 does not support this [State] element.
[In State] Protocol version 14.1 does not support this [State] element.
[In State] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [State] element.
[In State] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [State] element.

[In Status] The Status element is a required child element of the BodyPart element (section 2.2.2.10) that indicates the success or failure of the response in returning Data element content (section 2.2.2.20.2) given the BodyPartPreference element settings (section 2.2.2.11) in the request.
[In Status] The following table lists valid values [1, 176] for the Status element.
[In Status] [The value] 1 [of Status element] means Success.
[In Status] [The value] 176 [of Status element] means the message part is too large.
[In Status] Protocol version 12.1 does not support this [Status] element.
[In Status] Protocol version 14.0 does not support this [Status] element.
[In Status] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Status] element.
[In Status] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Status] element.
[In Status] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Status] element.
[In Street] The Street element is an optional child element of the Location element (section 2.2.2.27) that specifies the street address of the event's location.
[In Street] The Street element is a string data type, as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7.
[In Street] Protocol version 12.1 does not support this [Street] element.
[In Street] Protocol version 14.0 does not support this [Street] element.
[In Street] Protocol version 14.1 does not support this [Street] element.
[In Street] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Street] element.
[In Street] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Street] element.
[In Truncated] The Truncated element is a child element of the Body element (section 2.2.2.4) and the BodyPart element (section 2.2.2.5).
[In Truncated] The value of this element [the Truncated element] is a boolean value ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.1) that specified whether the body or body part has been truncated.

[In Truncated (Body)] The Truncated element is an optional child element of the Body element (section 2.2.2.4) that specifies whether the body of the item has been truncated according to the BodyPreference element (section 2.2.2.7) indicated by the client.
[In Truncated (Body)] If the value [of the Truncated element] is TRUE, then the body of the item has been truncated.
[In Truncated (Body)] If the value [of the Truncated element] is FALSE, or there is no Truncated element, then the body of the item has not been truncated.
[In Truncated (Body)] If a Truncated element is included in a command request, then it is ignored by the server.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Partially verified by derived requirement: MS-ASAIRS_R406.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Truncated (Body)] The server will return the same response no matter what the value of Truncated element is.
[In Truncated (Body)] A command response MUST have a maximum of one Truncated element per Body element.
[In Truncated (Body)] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [Truncated (Body)] element.
[In Truncated (Body)] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Truncated (Body)] element.
[In Truncated (Body)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Truncated (Body)] element.
[In Truncated (Body)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Truncated (Body)] element.
[In Truncated (Body)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Truncated (Body)] element.

[In Truncated (BodyPart)] The Truncated element is an optional child element of the BodyPart element (section 2.2.2.5) that specifies whether the body of the item has been truncated according to the BodyPartPreference element (section 2.2.2.6) indicated by the client.
[In Truncated (BodyPart)] If the value [of the Truncated element] is TRUE, then the body of the item has been truncated.
[In Truncated (BodyPart)] If the value [of the Truncated element] is FALSE, or there is no Truncated element, then the body of the item has not been truncated.
[In Truncated (BodyPart)] A command response MUST have a maximum of one Truncated element per BodyPart element.
[In Truncated (BodyPart)] Protocol version 12.1 does not support this [Truncated (BodyPart)] element.
[In Truncated (BodyPart)] Protocol version 14.0 does not support this [Truncated (BodyPart)] element.
[In Truncated (BodyPart)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Truncated (BodyPart)] element.
[In Truncated (BodyPart)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Truncated (BodyPart)] element.
[In Truncated (BodyPart)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Truncated (BodyPart)] element.
[In TruncationSize] The TruncationSize element is a child element of the BodyPartPreference element (section 2.2.2.6) and the BodyPreference element (section 2.2.2.7).

[In TruncationSize] The value of this element [the TruncationSize element] is an integer value ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.5) that specifies the size, in bytes, of the content that the user wants to search, synchronize, or fetch.
[In TruncationSize (BodyPartPreference)] The TruncationSize element is an optional child element of the BodyPartPreference element (section 2.2.2.6).
[In TruncationSize (BodyPartPreference)] A command request MUST have a maximum of one TruncationSize element per BodyPartPreference element.
[In TruncationSize (BodyPartPreference)] Command responses MUST NOT include the TruncationSize element.
[In TruncationSize (BodyPartPreference)] The TruncationSize element MUST have no child elements.
[In TruncationSize (BodyPartPreference)] The maximum value for TruncationSize is 4,294,967,295.
[In TruncationSize (BodyPartPreference)] If the TruncationSize element is absent, the entire content is used for the request.
[In TruncationSize (BodyPartPreference)] Protocol version 12.1 does not support this [TruncationSize (BodyPartPreference)] element.
[In TruncationSize (BodyPartPreference)] Protocol version 14.0 does not support this [TruncationSize (BodyPartPreference)] element.
[In TruncationSize (BodyPartPreference)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [TruncationSize (BodyPartPreference)] element.
[InTruncationSize (BodyPartPreference)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [TruncationSize (BodyPartPreference)] element.
[InTruncationSize (BodyPartPreference)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [TruncationSize (BodyPartPreference)] element.
[In TruncationSize (BodyPreference)] The TruncationSize element is an optional child element of the BodyPreference type (section 2.2.2.7).
[In TruncationSize (BodyPreference)] A command request MUST have a maximum of one TruncationSize element per BodyPreference element.
[In TruncationSize (BodyPreference)] Command responses MUST NOT include the TruncationSize element.
[In TruncationSize (BodyPreference)] The TruncationSize element MUST have no child elements.
[In TruncationSize (BodyPreference)] The maximum value for TruncationSize is 4,294,967,295.
[In TruncationSize (BodyPreference)] If the TruncationSize element is absent, the entire content is used for the request.
[In TruncationSize (BodyPreference)] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [TruncationSize (BodyPreference)] element.
[In TruncationSize (BodyPreference)] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [TruncationSize (BodyPreference)] element.
[In TruncationSize (BodyPreference)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [TruncationSize (BodyPreference)] element.
[In TruncationSize (BodyPreference)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [TruncationSize (BodyPreference)] element.
[In TruncationSize (BodyPreference)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [TruncationSize (BodyPreference)] element.

[In Type] The Type element is a child element of the Body element (section 2.2.2.4), the BodyPart element (section 2.2.2.5), the BodyPartPreference element (section 2.2.2.6), and the BodyPreference element (section 2.2.2.7).
[In Type] The value of this element[Type] is an unsignedByte value ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.8) that indicates the format type of the body content of the item.
[In Type] The following table defines the valid values [1, 2, 3, 4] of the Type element.
[In Type] [The value] 1 [of Type element] means Plain text.
[In Type] [The value] 2 [of Type element] means HTML.
[In Type] [The value] 3 [of Type element] means RTF.
[In Type] [The value] 4 [of Type element] means MIME.
[In Type (Body)] The Type element is a required child element of the Body element (section 2.2.2.9).
[In Type (Body)] A command request MUST have a maximum of one Type element per Body element.
[In Type (Body)] A command response MUST have a maximum of one Type element per Body element.
[In Type (Body)] The Type element MUST have no child elements.
[In Type (Body)] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [Type (Body)] element.
[In Type (Body)] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Type (Body)] element.
[In Type (Body)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Type (Body)] element.
[In Type (Body)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Type (Body)] element.
[In Type (Body)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Type (Body)] element.
[In Type (Body)] For calendar items in protocol version 16.0, the only valid values for this element [Type] is 1 (plain text).
[In Type (Body)] For calendar items in protocol version 16.1, the only valid values for this element [Type] is 1 (plain text).
[In Type (Body)] For calendar items in protocol version 16.0, the only valid values for this element [Type] is 2 (HTML).
[In Type (Body)] For calendar items in protocol version 16.1, the only valid values for this element [Type] is 2 (HTML).
[In Type (BodyPart)] The Type element is a required child element of the BodyPart element (section 2.2.2.10).
[In Type (BodyPart)] A command response MUST have a maximum of one Type element per BodyPart element.
[In Type (BodyPart)] The Type element MUST have no child elements.
[In Type (BodyPart)] Protocol version 12.1 does not support this [Type (BodyPart)] element.
[In Type (BodyPart)] Protocol version 14.0 does not support this [Type (BodyPart)] element.
[In Type (BodyPart)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Type (BodyPart)] element.
[In Type (BodyPart)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Type (BodyPart)] element.
[In Type (BodyPart)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Type (BodyPart)] element.
[In Type (BodyPartPreference)] The Type element is a required child element of the BodyPartPreference element (section 2.2.2.11).
[In Type (BodyPartPreference)] A command request MUST have a maximum of one Type element per BodyPartPreference element.
[In Type (BodyPartPreference)] The Type element MUST have no child elements.
[In Type (BodyPartPreference)] Only a value of 2 (HTML) SHOULD be used in the Type element of a BodyPartPreference element.
[In Type (BodyPartPreference)] Protocol version 12.1 does not support this [Type (BodyPartPreference)] element.
[In Type (BodyPartPreference)] Protocol version 14.0 does not support this [Type (BodyPartPreference)] element.
[In Type (BodyPartPreference)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Type (BodyPartPreference)] element.
[In Type (BodyPartPreference)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Type (BodyPartPreference)] element.
[In Type (BodyPartPreference)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Type (BodyPartPreference)] element.
[In Type (BodyPreference)] The Type element is a required child element of the BodyPreference element (section 2.2.2.12).
[In Type (BodyPreference)] A command request MUST have a maximum of one Type element per BodyPreference element.
[In Type (BodyPreference)] The Type element MUST have no child elements.
[In Type (BodyPreference)] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [Type (BodyPreference)] element.
[In Type (BodyPreference)] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Type (BodyPreference)] element.
[In Type (BodyPreference)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Type (BodyPreference)] element.
[In Type (BodyPreference)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Type (BodyPreference)] element.
[In Type (BodyPreference)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Type (BodyPreference)] element.
[In Groups] The following table summarizes the set of common XML schema group[TopLevelSchemaProps] definitions defined by this specification [MS-ASAIRS].
[In Groups] XML schema groups that are specific to a particular operation are described with the operation.

[In Groups] [The Group] TopLevelSchemaProps identifies the Body element (section 2.2.2.4), BodyPart element (section 2.2.2.5), and the Attachments element (section 2.2.2.3) as being part of the TopLevelSchemaProps group.

[In TopLevelSchemaProps] The TopLevelSchemaProps group identifies the Body element (section 2.2.2.4), the BodyPart element (section 2.2.2.5), and the Attachments element (section 2.2.2.3) as being part of the TopLevelSchemaProps group.
[In TopLevelSchemaProps] The TopLevelSchemaProps group is used by the ItemOperations command request specified in [MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.9.
[In TopLevelSchemaProps] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [TopLevelSchemaProps] element.
[In TopLevelSchemaProps] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [TopLevelSchemaProps] element.
[In TopLevelSchemaProps] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [TopLevelSchemaProps] element.
[In TopLevelSchemaProps] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [TopLevelSchemaProps] element.
[In TopLevelSchemaProps] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [TopLevelSchemaProps] element.
[In Commands] The following table lists the commands[ItemOperations, Search, Sync] that use the XML elements specified by this protocol[MS-ASAIRS].
[In Commands] [The Command] Itemoperations retrieves an item from the server.
[In Commands] [The Command] Search searches the server for items that match the specified criteria.
[In Commands] [The Command] Sync synchronizes changes in a collections set between the client and the server.

[In ItemOperations] The request message for the ItemOperations command can include the following elements: § FileReference (section 2.2.2.24.3) § BodyPreference (section 2.2.2.12) § Type (section 2.2.2.41.4) § TruncationSize (section 2.2.2.40.2) § AllOrNone (section 2.2.2.3.2) § Preview (section 2.2.2.35.4) § BodyPartPreference (section 2.2.2.11) § Type (section 2.2.2.41.3) § TruncationSize (section 2.2.2.40.1) § AllOrNone (section 2.2.2.3.1) § Preview (section 2.2.2.35.3) § Location (section 2.2.2.28) § DisplayName (section 2.2.2.22.3) § Annotation (section 2.2.2.6) § Street (section 2.2.2.38) § City (section 2.2.2.13) § State (section 2.2.2.36) § Country (section 2.2.2.19) § PostalCode (section 2.2.2.34) § Latitude (section 2.2.2.27) § Longitude (section 2.2.2.30) § Accuracy (section 2.2.2.1) § Altitude (section 2.2.2.4) § AltitudeAccuracy (section 2.2.2.5) § LocationUri (section 2.2.2.29)
